job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Portland, OR
pros: I love working on campus from the standpoint of working with students, being in an environment where people are looking to better themselves and being around lots of different people. The benefits were pretty decent.
cons: Pay is very low in comparison to other employers offering similar positions. Training for positions in my department was a nightmare and left several margins for error, often at the detriment to students looking for services. Management in my department was the worst managing experience I’ve ever had. It was very cliquey, no real accountability when it came to how problems actually arose due to poor training practices. No transparency when it came to providing feedback which made the feedback useless when there was no context for what I could improve on. Honestly felt like a lot of workplace bullying going on and it made me dread going to work everyday. Human Resources was useless even when I brought up several legal liability issues that I had pointed out from my experiences. I’m very disappointed with my time working for a university that I thought would be better. It’s a big red flag in my mind when I feel relieved to be leaving a job that I was initially really excited about.

job_title: Corporate Outreach Specialist in Portland, OR
pros:
Great, comprehensive benefits with only a very small employee match for healthcare. A phenomenal retirement plan. 15 hour a  month of  vacation time accrual. A culture of true commitment to increasing diversity at all levels and a genuine concern for staff work/life balance - IF you're not in management (they do work too much overtime). 

There are constant learning and training opportunities to gain skills on the job provided by the school as well as steeply discounted tuition. It is definitely a growth-oriented environment perfect for you if you want to be a lifelong learner.

The people who choose to work in education truly want to help others and as colleagues they are very supportive. The Academic Directors and faculty, at least in the School of Business (SB), are smart, interesting  people and are dedicated to helping students and to continuous improvement in how we serve students, as is leadership. There are plenty of intelligent, terrific women in teaching, management and senior leadership roles. 

You get to work with students who are making sacrifices and working hard to better their circumstances in life, and they are amazing, impressive, interesting, smart people. If you like helping people, it is tremendously gratifying to be part of their journey and some can become friends for life. Great for someone who wants to do meaningful work.
cons:
Thanks to our strong union, staff get a salary increase most years of 1 - 1.5% tied to the national COLA (cost of living) which is better than nothing but doesn't keep up with Portland's cola. My January rent increase is more than my salary increase! There aren't performance based raises, even when you're highly productive with excellent reviews, which can be very deincentivizing to say the least. In the last +/- 10 years, there has been no interest on the part of senior leadership to help staff find a path to career growth.  As an individual contributor, the only way to make more money is to manage people (change jobs). If you're ok with this, PSU SB is a terrific place to work with great people.

Hiring is much slower than in the for-profit business world, so when staff or managers leave our already lean teams, the remaining staff pick up the slack for a long wait until someone is hired. Some areas have been chronically understaffed for years (compared to similar size SBs at other Unis) so it is amazing how productive, adaptive and creative these teams are. Unfortunately, when you're streched too thin for too long it is impossible to fill everyone's expectations, and students sometimes don't realize how lean our teams are.

review_title: Depends on which department you work for
job_title: Computer Lab Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: It is a large university, so depending on which department you work for you may get taken advantage of or may have an amazing experience. As is typical with most universities, student labor is the glue that holds the place together, my department in particular was very respectful of this fact and recognized it's student employees frequently. I felt valued, and that I made a lasting impact before leaving.
cons: As a student laborer you make a meager wage, no benefits, have limited hours and are often indirectly asked to go above and beyond what your assigned duties are. Staff positions are always dangled in front of you as you move up, but often are crushed due to financial constraints. There is not much opportunity to move in the student labor force, which leads to a lack of motivation to continually do your best. There was no such thing as work life/balance in my position. I was often told I was not on call, but employees were told to call me, and part of the job description was to be available after hours. Frequent budget constraints led to conflicting (non-existent) policies about clocking hours outside of the office.

I personally was told I would receive support for my studies till I graduate. The entire situation changed once my supervisor hired a new blond chick. No accommodations at all, criticized and even encouraged to drop out of the job. Supervisors made up stories that I verbally abused them, during the time I had a harassment claim open. As a result, HR deemed my harassment claim inconclusive and closed it. It's a harsh reminder that HR works for the company - not for you. These are realities.

pros: Tuition is relatively low, compared to other American universities. The College of Engineering and Computer Science has good ties with the local high-tech companies, which is great especially for MS graduates, who can easily find a job after graduation.
cons:
If you are an International student, be aware that PSU does very little to make your life easy. The school is biased towards accepting international students coming with their own *full* funding (especially those who come with a full sponsorship from their country's government). If your sponsorship does not come from the outside, the school has policies in place to ensure the commitment to you on their side is limited in time, which forces you to take care of immigration issues very frequently.
The amount of bureaucracy is excessive, and you'll often find yourself bouncing between offices to get anything done.

review_title: Not the worst short-term employment, not the best
pros: Temp employment during and before their "rush week" period at the beginning of each term. (Positions have the ability to expand into permanent employment, but it seemed that the people who were hired for that longer-term employment had worked as temporary workers for multiple rushes before their hire.) Can get a lot of hours if you have open availability. There are textbook and supply discounts available, which is great if you're a student.
cons: Hires at minimum wage. Lots of boring downtime between heavy rushes. They overhired for the rush I worked, so they ended up not giving us as many hours in the last week as we'd been led to expect. Training was often informal, but "learning as you go" doesn't always work when the store is busy and you, as a cashier, don't know how to work some important aspect of the register system.

review_title: Really amazing place to learn pretty much anything you wanted to know about IT - there's no other environment like it.
job_title: Operating Systems Network Analyst II in Portland, OR
pros: Extremely dynamic environment, my team has awesome management and listens to my input. We complete dozens of really big projects a year on time and everyone loves us :).
cons: Pay I would say is honestly the biggest problem here. Its roughly 50% less than industry standard for what I do, and there's very little framework in place to get that bumped up. They rather let you go to another employer in fact than bump your pay - which I think is foolish as it will probably cost them more in the short term to hire another person than to just fix their pay scales.

review_title: A great place to work, learn, and grow
pros:
Low stress, flexible hours, focus on employee engagement, great benefits, advancement opportunities.  

Access to the rec center (gym, pool, fitness classes, etc) is convenient and affordable, maybe around $35/month.

We get to choose one conference or training event to go to each year.  There are typically a few other career advancement opportunities throughout the year that do not require travel.

We are encouraged to take the time to learn new skills (rather than just rushing to get things done as quickly as possible).
cons:
Located in downtown Portland, so commuting can be a real pain if you have to drive.

While there are opportunities to work with new technologies, we also have to support some old outdated technologies.

Some people complain that the pay is lower than the private sector.  I feel like we are very fairly compensated, especially when you factor in the value of our benefits package and retirement plan. Not to mention the low stress and work-life balance that I hear is not so common in the private sector.

job_title: Peer Mentor/Academic Express Advising in Portland, OR
pros: The interview process, training, and mentoring opportunities are fantastic. The supervisor of student employees is fair, accessible and supportive. There are full time academic advisers there, as well, who are available to assist the student workers in answering complex questions. They are always ready to help, and their collective knowledge (of a system which is inherently full of red tape) is nothing short of astonishing. The networking opportunities in this office are countless, and you will grow your customer service skills and be part of a team that helps students to succeed. The SBA undergrad academic advising office is widely known around campus as one of the best, most professionally run at PSU.
cons: There are not many cons, really. the pay is low, but it is a student position. They do offer extra hours on occasion, but generally it runs 4-5 hours per week. Not a good fit if you need tons of hours.

review_title: IT is a Great Place to Work
job_title: Information Technology Manager in Portland, OR
pros:
OIT is it's own bubble and is arguably the best place to work on campus.  It is a great work environment and you have great work life balance.  You have all the tools you need within reason, and opportunities for professional growth.

Senior IT management listens to their employees and sets priorities and expectations realistically.

Benefits are fantastic (Health, retirement, vacation, sick).
cons:
The politics can cause work that reaches outside of OIT to move very slowly.

OIT is somewhat isolated on campus so you must be proactive to feel engaged and connected to the mission.

Budgets are tight but the effect on OIT is mitigated because the Presidents Office understands that OIT provides critical services to campus.

Pay is arguably on the low end but reasonable when considering total compensation.

Dealing with employees through the union can be a challenge.

 IT staffing levels are low which causes frustration among employees when the are not able to take on work they know should be addressed.

review_title: These types of positions are unique, so are hard to generalize.
job_title: Adjunct Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: I have flexibility with work scheduling. The research work is interesting and help build skills. I have working in labs with a great set of co-workers, and I have also been in environments that are more difficult. My latest position has had a fair wage.
cons: The type of positions I get are funding dependent and typically limited duration.  They are always part-time in order to keep me benefits ineligible and stretch the budget. This is the nature of the beast, and I accept it. Working in this type of position is essentially and bridge job to other things. It hard to rely on this for an extended period of time, and one should really be looking for other work simultaneously.

review_title: Large bureaucratic institution struggles to modernize, some bright lights
pros: Wonderful location - downtown Portland.  Loads of public transportation options.  Very student-focused - lots of first generation and older students.  The most diverse campus in Oregon.  Lots of international students and a a stated international focus. President is trying to capitalize on the strengths of the institutions.  Excellent IT help desk.
cons: Old legislative mandates require an overwhelming amount of "work-around." Departments are very siloed - little interdisciplinary activity.  Little or no faculty support.  Increasing pressure for adjuncts over tenure and fixed term appointments.  Low salaries, eroding benefits.  Terrible parking. Facilities are worn and shabby, sometimes to an embarrassing degree.  Increasingly intrusive health care oversight. Few eating options.

review_title: Awesome life/work balance.  Very little management direction and structure.
pros: Depending on your manager, you can have a really great job with a lot of autonomy to fulfill your personal and professional mission.  Life work balance is extraordinary.  There are pockets of deeply committed professionals that make working here a joy and a daily learning experience.
cons:
Lack of information and direction from senior management.  
fund balance accounting makes it impossible to ever know where your program/department/school is according to projections.  
The ability 
A huge number of disenfranchised mid-level managers that bleeds all over their employees.
There are random individuals that are extremely poor workers who know there is nothing anyone can do to them to get rid of them.

pros: Location in beautiful downtown Portland "Cultural District." Urban university that ideally could be  force for innovation in the community.
cons: Paralyzed by constant infighting by mediocre dept. heads and oblivious deans. What's left needs a serious review, both for transparency and accountability. Constant internal squabbling over which agency will pay for what; to the extent that a brand new building lacked wireless internet for months because no unit in the organization wanted to be "stuck" paying for it if they could find a way for another one to foot the bill

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: GRA position waived most of my tuition saving me thousands in student loan debt. On top of the tuition waiver, I was paid well. Beyond the pay and cost savings, one of the biggest benefits of this position was the opportunity to conduct and publish research, attend and present at conference, and make great professional connections. All staff knew I was a student, so they were incredibly considerate and understanding of working remotely, scheduling hours outside of finals week, etc. They placed a lot of emphasis on career development, too.
cons: It's a temporary position by nature. The GRAs are competitive and there's no guarantee you'll be matched up to an opportunity that suits your interests. Mine wasn't a perfect match to my career goals but I am so grateful for the opportunity nonetheless.

review_title: Group X Instructor At Campus Rec
job_title: Group X Instructor in Portland, OR
pros:
Lots of development opportunity and means of gaining experience.
Great student coordinator and lead coordinator.
Positive and helpful environment.
They really care about student wellbeing and being inclusive.
cons: 1/2-1/4 the pay of working as a group x instructor anywhere else. You do not get paid anything for the hours you will spend writing lesson plans. Employees get no additional benefits. You can't bring anyone into the gym for free,  even to come to your class as a group x instructor. Pay is $14 an hour, and it's $7 to bring someone to your class. If you bring a friend to your class, that's half of your pay right there.

review_title: An organization transforming itself with 100% leadership turnover in last 2 years.
pros: The opportunity to contribute and transform the lives of others through development of critical thinking skills and career development.  It can be rewarding to learn how lives have been transformed having been provided the opportunity for an advanced degree.  Higher Education is also a very collaborative environment.
cons: Very politically motivated leadership focused on bringing change of maturity to the organization.  Exactly what that is and how varies by department and unit making for uncertainty.  The industry is in on the cusp of significant change - cost vs value, MOOCs, graduation rates.  State fiscal support of public state schools has been significantly limited while the State oversite structure is also being modified with the combining of K-12, CC and universities.  The mantra is do more with less efficiently.

pros: There are a number of highly motivated students at the school and working with them can be incredibly satisfying. Coworkers were incredibly friendly and welcoming. The work-life balance was great. I worked a 40 hour week. Period. I was never stressed and didn't work weekends or nights.
cons: The work itself was interesting, but honestly not enough. The pace of PSU was incredibly slow; I would be assigned work to last the week that I would wrap up in under a day or months-long projects that I could tackle in a week. This is not to toot my own horn, it was just that the staff had no sense of urgency and there was a general lack of drive.

pros: Huge focus on employee experience within the Office of Information Technology (OIT).  Management centers on autonomy, mastery, and purpose for everyone in OIT.  Employees not only have clear goals within their area of ownership, but also can work on any project of their choosing on regularly scheduled AMP days.  Department , team , and individual training are scheduled every year; all university classes are available at a huge discount; continuous development is encouraged.  The purpose of the University is clear, and OIT is the foundation of the computing for that purpose.
cons: As with any University and small business, there are only a few steps up available for an IT employee.

review_title: Great graduate program for research and teaching
pros: The chemistry department at PSU has a talented and growing group of faculty doing world-class research.  The department is well-run and led the university in funding derived from grants written by and awarded to the faculty while I was there. The environment is very cooperative and students have access to a variety of state-of-the-art instrumentation.  The research groups are small enough to get to know everyone and doors are nearly always open.  I was satisfied with the work-life balance in the lab I worked in.  The location is great, downtown and easy to get to, yet close enough to desirable, affordable places to live.
cons: Funding was limited at times due to government cutbacks.

job_title: Adjunct Business Instructor in Portland, OR
pros: I was relocating to the Portland metro area and reached out to the Accounting Department at the School of Business Administration. The department chair placed me in the adjunct pool and said she might have a couple of course that needed to be covered. She contacted me in April and I'll be teaching this fall.
cons: This is more of an industry downside (or upside depending which side of the coin you are on), but waiting for a full-time position can take several years. Accounting professors/full-time instructors don't seem to retire often, but it's a good gig so why would they leave.

review_title: University does not live up to its vast potential
pros: The downtown location near transit, food carts, and other amenities was awesome. The benefits, as a publicly funded institution are above average.
cons: Upper management does not live up to the hype.  It is very easy to become " pigeonholed" into a specific job, leaving little room for advancement.  Very low pay compared to market conditions.  Initiative is not encouraged nearly as much as it should be.

pros:
Your coworkers and management can be lifesaving
Free food and access to career and academic networking makes work a lot more fun 
There is always something to do, and helping prospective students and their families figure out if this is the right fit for themselves or their loved ones is very special
cons:
Prospective Students and their families often snap, leaving you feeling like an emotionally abused mop
It really depends on whose managing your department, some are very well oiled machines and others less so

review_title: Great Variety of Jobs, Reasonable Management
pros: I have had a couple jobs as a student at PSU. Some jobs have more perks than others,  and the one I have is by far my favorite. The supervisors and managers are reasonable and understanding, whether I have a midterm or paper that is due the next week to arranging a work schedule for breaks. Flexible in scheduling, and PSU understands class has priority over work. Meet new classmates and cohorts.
cons: Work can be dull during the breaks and summers.  Some classmates can be self centered and self serving.

pros: Nice facility in business school, very engaging colleagues at the adjunct level
cons: Department heads and Dean's office never communicate with part time and adjunct staff, no feedback on performance other than student ratings, if you wish to teach a particular class it is difficult to get the attention of department heads, top management seems oblivious to the wants/needs of lower level professors, I rarely know in advance if I am being considered for teaching a course, I can't plan when I work at PSU

review_title: Work with many smart, creative colleagues
job_title: Web Communications Lead in Portland, OR
pros: So many folks on staff and faculty are wise, funny, caring and dedicated. Opportunities to collaborate across units are plentiful if you look for them.
cons: It's tempting and easy to focus all of your energies on your own unit. Also, a few units experience a lot of employee turnover, making for inconsistent services and information from those units.

job_title: Human Interaction Support Specialist in Portland, OR
pros:
Working at Portland State is relaxing. This review is from the perspective of the user support in the Maseeh College.

Users come to us with real problems we're presented the opportunity to solve, and the students as a collective run the college's IT organization, which is a fun and inspiring process.
cons: As with any tech support job, sometimes people will just ask you to fix it and not care what the solution is. This leads to needing to solve the same problem multiple times.

pros: Learning about new cultures, upward mobility, casual and fun work environment, lots of freedom. Supervisors are there if you need them but will otherwise let you work independently without hanging over your shoulder. Everybody is incredibly friendly, patient, and open to being asked questions, no matter how silly.
cons: Not many hours available, though scheduling is extremely flexible, as it is a student position. Low pay to begin with, but can increase. Work environment: absolutely no windows in the entire place, almost all fluorescent lighting. Can sometimes be difficult to separate work and play if you don't set boundaries early on.

pros:
People from all over the world trying to achieve their goals and you get to help. Fun colleagues and a lot of flexibility depending on the dept. Great benefits, including an awesome deal on tuition, rec center. Room from growth. I have spent most of my career there and I have done most of the things I set out to. 

As an urban access school with great programs you see everything you can imagine!
cons: Complexity, a lot of turn over, and a lot of pretty basic stuff that could be better. Usually change means making things more, rather than less complex.

review_title: Center for Student Health and Counseling
pros:
- There are some smart, kind folks who care about supporting students with their education
- PSU provides great benefits
- There is a lot of stability since once you've hit 6 months, it's much, much harder for the university to lay you off or fire you
- Family-friendly
cons:
- There are some people, especially in management, who have been there for so long that they've become complacent and do a subpar job, become overly pessimistic/jaded, and/or get very set in their ways so it's hard to implement change, which was frustrating.
- Favoritism was huge; it was not always a healthy work environment.
- Less competitive salary/wage

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Portland, OR
pros: A typical campus job. Low skill required, they work with your schedule. Easy work, especially on weekends when it is not very busy. Pleasant atmosphere working with peers and the staff is friendly, funny, and helpful.
cons: The pay is low and there appear to be no opportunities for raises. There was no training other than on the job. High turnover, though that is to be expected for a campus job. Some peers don't seem to be very helpful and have questionable competency. Professors who are supported via help desk often have obnoxious egos (which is odd since they ask elementary questions).

review_title: Getting better, can't get no worse.
pros: Great campus location in beautiful downtown Portland. New bargaining agreement for faculty, new university president engaged for Fall 2008 could change things for the better.
cons: Culture of underachievement by administration; over reliance on contingent teaching laber creates a division within the faculty. Teaching is undervalued, but not fully funded as a research institution. Very little opportunity to advance within the organization.

pros: It was easy to transition here from being a student. I have spent nearly ten years at PSU in a student and staff environment. The tuition discount is 70%, and it is a very good discount, but hard to make use of.
cons: The pay sucks. The days off suck. There are no flexible part-time graduate degrees. The parking situation also sucks. I work OT every day and every week but I am not allowed to cash it in. I also cannot take days off even though in a year I have accrued over a month off in OT. There are no promotions.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Portland, OR
pros:
Tuition Reimbursement + Stipend
You have an office
Work computer provided (if you ask for one)
PSU has some interesting and diverse culture.  Expect fun coworkers and colleagues.
cons:
Tuition Reimbursement doesn't cover all enrollment fees.
Stipend isn't enough to live off of.  Should be compensated more for how much work you do.
Shared office ( you have to share it )
Work Computer ( might as well use your laptop, they're slow )

review_title: Great organization To Work For, Horrible HR Department, even worse Administration!
pros: Great departments that are dedicated to serving the true and real needs of students, parents, international students, faculty, administrators, and the greater Portland , Oregon, and regional community. Outstanding classified employees that keep the University top notch in every way, and running in every important way, even though they are very under paid, but top notch people. Excellent departmental management, especially in one of the most important departments, Financial Services, formerly known as the Bursar's Office.
cons: The HR department that is almost off campus and in another world, is staffed by bureaucrats, so called managers, and staff who have no earthly idea what goes on at the university, what happens everyday with classified employees, and does what it can to get rid of valuable employees who might have health issues and who could easily do their jobs just as well from home, something the state of Oregon and the Oregon University Systems, the agency that governs all state of Oregon universities, encourages strongly, but doesn't get carried out by PSU HR due to incompetence. Many excellent employees in all departments have been laid off and terminated because HR is so far removed from what the university actually does everyday and have no idea what they are doing and how their actions affect the students, parents, and departments as a whole. To many people in HR there only for the money, something they wont pay in a fair way to classified employees. For reference consider the HR scandal with the University Hotel and how management botched and took advantage of immigrant and diverse employees at the university owned hotel.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Some nice new facilities/laboratories shared with the other university in town (OHSU)
cons: Salaries for graduate students are not livable, especially considering the increasing cost of living in Portland and the lack of any raises for several years in a row. Management is non-existent. Violations of rules are a commonplace thing at PSU. These include cases of harassment (one of my students was harassed under my watch), radiation safety violations (happened in my lab), advisors not sticking to firm/formal deadlines (long list of incidents). Complaints (formal or informal) are entirely pointless and will not accomplish anything. Departments don't effectively communicate with each other, including matters of immigration and registration.

review_title: Underfunded university with a noble mission
pros: Admirable mission of serving the underserved. World-class faculty who work at PSU because they want to live in Portland. Excellent partnerships with city government, community groups, and local industry.
cons: Highly divergent views about what the university’s priorities should be between longtime and more recently hired faculty. Strong influence of unions  that tend to have an adversarial relationship with administration. Insufficient support from the state of Oregon, given the essential role the university plays in educating first-generation  and working adult students.

review_title: A management nightmare that doesn't support creativity & growth
pros: The faculty and peers I worked with were great, but many were quite frustrated
cons: Very poor management, toxic environment, squelches creativity, new ideas and innovation.

pros: Colleagues are great. The AAUP Union is strong and has student support. Benefits are pretty good. You pay 95% of medical benefits, though it use to be 100% when I first started. You can take courses at 30% of the cost. The park blocks are nice during the summer. Faculty and staff genuinely care about the students and integrity of academics.
cons:
There are no professional development opportunities unless you take courses on campus or pursue outside educational opportunities. My supervisors have never supported professional development and have continuously denied requests. Money is always an excuse, but I've also been denied when I have offered to pay out of pocket. There are no opportunities for growth---it's a dead end job. Additionally, there are not a lot of opportunities to move to other departments. Even if you do a great job, raises are only through the union contract. There are a lot of middle and upper management bloat. It costs $108 or so per month to pay for on campus parking and about $50 for a tri-met pass. There is not a lot of support for the President. The school seems to be pushing towards a corporate model way of doing business. 

Pay is not up to par with the required experience and education level (graduate) for this position. Most of my advising colleagues have several masters degrees and/or ten or more years of experience. You cannot negotiate your starting wage. Many of my colleagues are also working other jobs to pay for student loans and to try to save for future housing plans. There are no incentives for hard work. There is a lack of diversity support. Departments are understaffed. There are a lot of managers/supervisors that do not know how to manage.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Portland, OR
pros:
Flexible with timings, no pressure on self if a part of work is done wrong or delayed due to other factors like classes, exams etc. Great Professor-Student relationship and very care taking behavior.
Amazing pay, with instate fees and tuition remission along with monthly stipend. Enough money to pay off the fees for entire quarter.
cons: Sometimes overloaded with assignments and computer programs to evaluate, beyond the working hours. But still fine because you are getting paid (really a very good pay) as a student.

review_title: PSU BOOKSTORE: Good for a college kid but not a career..
pros: Flexible schedule, small community, convenient downtown location.
cons: Poor management. The bookstore is not part of the university and has changed owners about 6+ times in the last 7 years. If you are looking for a career and are not a current student at PSU, I do not recommend wasting your time.

pros: The main incentive is the excellent benefits given to Oregon University employees. It costs me almost nothing to insure myself and my husband plus life insurance, PTO, disability, etc. PSU has a great academic culture but is conveniently located in the downtown area. They provide discount Trimet passes which saves money. Positions are often union represented.
cons: Rigid schedule, at least my position. Change happens slowly - as is typical of a nonprofit organization. The role can become monotonous and dull. Takes a long time to advance and even when you do salary doesn't reflect your qualifications.

pros: It is a great place to work if you are a student. There are willing to work around your class schedule and are pretty understanding when it comes to the work and school life balance.
cons: I can think of any cons at this time, well maybe a part con. The pay for the job and work we do here is not what it should be. Entry level positions for this type of work is way higher than what students are being paid to help manage and Enterprise level network such as this.

pros: A great deal of one's day-to-day experience depends upon what department you are in. If you have good colleagues, it can be a congenial place to work.
cons: The administration treats the faculty as employees of a corporation, not as partners. The University is strapped for money, and faculty positions are precarious. Each year there are cuts in departmental budgets. There is a great deal of anxiety among the faculty about job security. The number of administrators has increased greatly over the last decade while faculty positions have been cut.

review_title: Great Urban Downtown location, Great Students and Profs, but Administration needs a complete overhaul
pros: The university offers good benefits (though this is changing), a great urban downtown location, good professors and students, and you get to be part of one of the biggest Oregon universities
cons: Administration needs a complete overhaul.  Huge Bureaucracy.  Employees hired and fired within only several months because upper management decided to change its mind.  Culture of backstabbing and lack of internal control.  Too much politic-ing and not enough rewarding performance.

pros: I am always treated with respect by management and HR, which is really nice. I am in a student position and it's the best job I've had so far. You have responsibilities and work to do, but everyone is very respectful and professional. You're able to pick your own hours and have a consistent, 3 month schedule that changes each term. They promote from within and have lots of different opportunities for extra pay and promotions.
cons: None that I can think of!

review_title: Great employer if you can find the right niche
pros: Some departments run more smoothly than others - if you can find a smooth running department, you'll enjoy good people and the general excitement of working in a university environment.
cons: The place is huge and as such there is a lot of red tape and regulation, and sometimes it can feel like it takes months to get a single thing approved or checked off your list.

pros: Opportunity to work with some incredibly creative people who care about students.  These were people from departments outside of OIT.
cons: Everything is treated as a project with little thought to long term strategy, planning, training or future university needs or goals.  Alot of time spent covering short comings of organization and unity (Finance and Admin).

pros: It's location in the City of Portland.  It is a university with great potential.
cons: Because of its geographical location it attracts high quality faculty despite chronically low salaries.  The university does not do enough to retain the people it attracts. Administrators are often selected from the ranks of faculty without enough attention being given to their managerial or business competencies.

job_title: Desktop Support Techniian in Portland, OR
pros: Worked close to school, flexible schedule, PSU still has an IT department which is nice, they have control over their environment still.
cons: Not the most respected position, but most people I worked with really liked my support. Pay was minimal, but that is expected in a position like this.

review_title: Bureaucracy Swamp of Tears and Resentment
pros: As individuals, the people are great excepting some of the tenured faculty and more draconian Finance staff. The campus is lovely, transit access and proximity to food carts are great; basically everything other than asking the institution to actually function is great.
cons: The stodgy, hostile, money-grubbing politics that plays out between departments, and between the administrative and academic sides, weigh this institution way down. I hated working here because great people with great projects had no power to help each other.

pros: Medical benefits and retirement are excellent provided you are hired full-time or on the tenure track.
cons: There is a push for online education but the institution will not provide resources for proctored testing.  The current contract requires you to hand over your course intellectual property, exams, syllabus, etc., so that the course you create can be taught without you for a year.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Flexibility in hours and approach to work. Lots of opportunity to get involved in different projects and topics. High degree of autonomy.
cons: Mentoring is only available if you demand it. Clear communication about research goals and hypotheses is not always up to par. Update meetings are infrequent and often end up in just chit chat.

pros: With several bus lines leading directly to campus, its a convinient location.  The people are friendly and laid back and very supportive.
cons: I am a graduate assistant.  My position is contract, there are no benefits, and it is temporary by nature.  This would be a great place to work as a "real" employee.

review_title: A great way to pay for your education and learn valuable skills
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Working as a graduate research assistant puts you in close contact with the upper echelons of academia, which lets you see where the cutting edge of your field is heading. It also is an excellent way to pay for your education.
cons: You will work many hours and will likely be underpaid for your work. Unfortunately this is the way it goes in academia, and comes with the territory. Also, you are juggling many different responsibilities.

review_title: Calibrations and Testing Business Center up to 2013
pros: working in an R&D organization opened opportunities to learn and collaborate with professionals from diverse  fields.
cons: testing and calibration was not in the main stream operations of many companies back then in Botswana but there were opportunities for market growth.

pros: I am able to choose my own working  hours.  Students are wonderful. An engaging and intellectual atmosphere in which to work.
cons: There are no benefits and full-time faculty are not very inclusive of part-time faculty.  In my department communication is not great.  There need to be more faculty meetings with adjunct faculty being invited to participate.

pros: Working on this beautiful, dynamic, downtown campus is the only good thing about working here.
cons: Communication is terrible.  There are so many closed door meetings and nothing ever comes out of them. There is no advantage to being a University employee when you are looking for opportunities on campus, you have to apply for the position just like anyone from outside of campus, so why apply here?

pros: Most of the staff are reliable, hardworking employees who are genuinely working to make education better and affordable to students.
cons: Managers will step on you to make themselves look better. The state continues to attack staff wages and pensions while making sure that executives are well compensated. Executive bloat is evident.

review_title: If you are looking for a diverse working environment, it will be a good place for you!
job_title: Student Accounting Assistant in Portland, OR
pros:
Great location in downtown Portland. There are lots of food carts around. 
People are so nice and willing to help you. 
Good compensation
cons:
Need to improve management operation.
Hard to get promotion
If you are a student and have a part-time job there, you won't get more change to be a full-time employers after graduating. 
Lack of Internal control

job_title: Marketing Communications Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: My experience working at PSU was okay. Great benefits and time off for non-classified staff. Had freedom to make decisions and dictate direction for a small unit on campus.
cons: I came from a university that was on a steady growth trajectory so the unrealized potential of this place was so frustrating. The university has issues with hiring the wrong people. The university is over leveraged monetarily. Student enrollment is very erratic and makes planning extremely difficult.

pros: Good work environment, fulfilling work, and convenient location (can't beat taking classes and working in the same location). Full tuition remission with graduate assistantship.
cons: Hard to get by on the monthly living stipend, and there's not much communication between departments, which makes some tasks much more difficult than they should be.

pros: As a teaching assistant they pay full tuition fee and pay about 550$ per month for sixteen hours a week
cons: AS a student its very difficult to get oncampus job at portland state university. Getting funding in your curriculum atleast engineering is easy.

job_title: IT Student Employee in Portland, OR
pros: Very flexible about scheduling. Supportive about success as a student. Tries to taylor tasks to interests and professional development. Very nice to have work and school in one place.
cons: Jobs can get tedious. Outdated systems and bureaucratic management create a significant portion of the problems.

job_title: Marketing & Communications Graduate Assistant — School of Business in Portland, OR
pros:
- Valuable real world work experience similar to internship or contract hire
- Good flexibility — able to focus on school when necessary
- Huge cost savings on graduate education
- Leads to valuable connections with the Portland business community
cons:
- As a temporary position,  work responsibilities generally do not scale up much over time
- Slim budgets leave some work teams spread thin with not much resources
- University-wide institutional constraints can limit department autonomy

review_title: Opportunity to build experience and great coworkers.
job_title: Housing Assistant- Student in Portland, OR
pros: I was allowed to use my phone and do homework while on the job. As long as you are attentive to customers and your coworkers. It was awesome being allowed to study when it was slow.
cons: The job is really customer service orientated. People can be really difficult sometimes and I often found myself drained from answering so many emails and phone calls.

pros: Offered flexibility while going to school (schedule, studying at work). Convenient location if you live on/near campus; easy public transportation ride if you live in the city. Great co-workers. Mostly relaxed environment and culture.
cons: Bureaucracy (I really hated sucking up to all the people who felt they were more important than me)! Low student pay and minimal raises. Difficult parking.

job_title: Systems Analyst II in Portland, OR
pros: Discount tuition, flexible work hours, quiet work life.  Great retirement plan (PEBB).
cons: Everything moves slow.  Technologies are up to a decade behind the times.  Many of your coworkers are people who attended Portland State, then got a job at Portland State, and have no other work experience.  Due to the state retirement plan there are lots of lifers.

pros:
My boss and co-workers were flexible with me taking breaks during the day to take classes. They were supportive of me furthering my education. 
Loved the faculty and other co-workers. 
Love working in a higher ed environment where people value intelligence and diversity.
cons: The volume of the work could get overwhelming at times.

job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Portland, OR
pros: Flexible hours, good experience with lots of room to grow. Worked on a lot of projects that I learned a lot from.
cons: Low pay, lots of bureaucracy with little room to move up. Clients were hard to pin down sometimes but they were great people.

review_title: OK student job, no room for much more
pros: Pros - Flexible work schedule, government holidays off, recently granted sick leave time for student employees
cons: No real room for advancement, organizational change effectively lost in bureaucracy and politics.

review_title: Varies hugely from dep't to dep't
pros: amazing array of people and potential experiences.  PSU offers amazing diversity and a wealth of experiences.  There are some truly exceptional people.
cons: There is some small to large potential of being placed in a department where the leadership is out of touch with both customer and employee needs.  Many of the same pitfalls of any large bureaucracy.

job_title: Computer Science Tutor in Portland, OR
pros: Wonderful coworkers and environment, flexible hours. It's a typical school job. Since its with the university they are even more understanding than other places would be regarding your education.
cons: Not much room for growth on your wages. These are primarily student jobs that will remain constant.

review_title: Friendly environment but less opportunities to grow
pros: Friendly environment.Hard to tell the pros.All pros are cons.No pros really, have to give stress to my brain to think about pros.
cons: Small number of opportunities to enhance knowledge,small package.No career development.No opportunities to grow.Worst place to work.Dreadful experience.

pros: hours are very flexible, the managers are nice and understanding. you can always depend on your co-workers to cover for you when you need some time off, which was fantastic.
cons: The work load can get really repetitive and boring. Internet access is only to school websites which makes the work at the front desk long and heavy, especially that it is not always very busy.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Graduate assistants have recently won union recognition and can now fight for better compensation. Further organization for a campus wide increase of the minimum wage is ongoing.
cons: Sharp annual increases in additional fees (i.e., tuition, health care, building fee, incidental fee, etc.) and low base salary for many GA's. Also compensation depends strongly on departments with engineering GA's often making significantly more for the same job title.

pros:
Working with students directly
Staying fresh on lecture material
Decent pay for part time student worker
Flexible schedules and can work from anywhere
cons:
Pay could be better, but I can't complain
Offering TA positions for more courses would be a great opportunity for other students.

review_title: Very Poor Upper management in PSU Accounting office.
job_title: IT Support In Accounting in Portland, OR
pros: The non-management employees are mostly nice.
cons: Director level Managers are toxic. No level of trust. Poor communications skills. They assume rather than ask employees for any explanations with regard to ANYTHING. Pretty arrogant. Current IT accounting employees are worried about new people coming in and being better employees. There is no IT support team in accounting. Just people trying to keep their fiefdoms in tact.

job_title: Lecturer/Graduate Teaching Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: The academic environment is a joy to work in. As adjunct faculty I had a lot of control over how I ran my class.
cons: Whether I would have employment in the next academic quarter depended on enrollment and class availability, and as part time adjunct faculty I was the last to be offered a class to teach. This is the nature of the position.

pros:
- Working with collegiate athletes.
- Chance to do a little bit of everything.
cons:
- Facilities are not up to par with a bigger University
- Communication was less than ideal
- Good luck finding a parking lot
- Pay is very minimal

review_title: You Think It Would Be Fun to Work in a University...
job_title: Assistant to the Director in Portland, OR
pros:
Best benefits - 95% coverage for health and retirement benefits
Very cheap tuition for PSU, U of O and OSU for you or your family
Downtown Portland
Relaxed Environment
cons:
Faculty don't respect staff (think they are secretaries)
Paper-pusher, boring jobs (there's a reason they think staff are secretaries)
Union employees who aren't rewarded to work harder, just stay put longer

review_title: Supportive environment that was centered on the student lifestyle of needing to balance work with school achievement
pros: Quiet environment; supportive staff; was able to be both independent and work as part of a team.
cons: Dead end job due to it being a student position

review_title: Little room to advance for non-academic staff
pros: A Vibrant campus community in the heart of Downtown Portland, lots of mass transit options
cons: For the last decade, has had budget problems so that wages for most are stagnant, Has also had 4 presidents in that time as well as lots of turnover in the administration.

pros: Super flexible scheduling, they allow you to work on homework when things get slow, and they always seem to have a great team to work with.
cons: Minimum wage (or just above), and you're limited in how many hours you can work. Sometimes the work gets repetitive, but that's to be expected from a part-time, on-campus student job.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros:
Knowledgeable professors with lots of industry experience.
Good financial support
cons:
All graduate classes are at night.
Little effort to build rapport with students.
Graduates students are isolated from each other.
Professors can be a bit out of touch.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: PSU has great benefits and working downtown is great.
cons: I was one of only two postdocs in the department (large department). The school definitely is not a research institute, so do not expect that kind of culture. Most postdocs are not payed full time so the faculty can save money, but they are expected to work crazy hours.

pros:
- great place for a long-term, secure position
- strong unions in place that have helped, especially in times like COVID to stop full furloughs
- great work/life balance
- excellent health benefits for full-time employees
cons:
- limited opportunities for advancement
- slow to change status quo in terms of expanding scope of work or projects/ taking on new initiatives

pros:
Students can get broad experience and construction design while going to school.
Not bad pay for freshmen ($12-$13/h) considering it's on campus
cons:
Must balance schedule to not interfere with grades
You have to look for work to do and ask around otherwise you might not get any

pros: Portland State is great for connections being in the middle of the city and the diverse clientele that come through the campus. It is a caring community that wants to help you do better.
cons: It is a big university so there is a lot of loopholes, waiting for things to get approved through various channels.

job_title: Director of Human Resources in Portland, OR
pros: Great employee environment, intelligent and passionate staff, involved and integral to the Portland community
cons: Small and horizontal so no room for growth.  But we know that and develop you to leave and find a great job somewhere else.

pros: Great retirement package. Great work life balance. There are pros and cons to working at any place. I enjoy the pros here enough.
cons: Not much room for career advancement. It can feel very isolated even though you're part of a big institution because each unit operates as a small little business.

pros: Very supportive environment, great work-life balance, promotes continuing education and professional development, reduced tuition benefit for employee and spouse
cons: Very beaurocratic, takes a long time to get anything done, pay is less than you could get in the private sector

pros: Faculty and staff are committed to students. Deeply embedded culture of social justice and environmental sustainability. Great location.
cons: Limited advancement opportunities. Compensation is not competitive, and most departments are under-resourced due to funding cuts. Extremely bureaucratic. Difficult to get things done or perform to potential.

review_title: Great benefits, no raises.  Ever.  No matter how 'exceptional' your evaluations are.
pros: Benefits.  That's about it.  Not much else to say.
cons: Salaries (except for upper management) are stagnant.  Accounted for inflation, I'm making LESS than I was when I started working there seven years ago.

pros:
Great location, up and coming university. Wide range of bachelor, master, doctorate programs, commitment to community connections.
Increased focus on research. 
Wide range of students in age, backgrounds, etc.
cons: Fast changing environment can make priorities unclear. Great benefits balanced by mediocre pay. Nicer new and remodeled facilities, but still some old buildings/eyesores.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Gain the experience in college teaching and the job can payoff the tuition.
cons: You need to spend extra time on teaching which is helpful if your career goal is a college teacher. But if you want to go to other industries, it might be not relevant with your professional skill set.

job_title: Student Program Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: PSU motivates and trains their full-time staff to treat student employees well--it's extremely flexible, a lot of jobs are chill, and my position gave me opportunities to actively help other students and learn new skills relevant to my future career.
cons: Oftentimes these student positions don't pay well. It is what it is.

pros: Support from management is a strong point I would like to highlight. Flexible work environment.
cons: The only con would be the parking. It's not bad for working downtown but could be better.

job_title: Research Lab Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Will work around school schedule, and the pay is good for the amount of work that is put in.
cons: Not many cons, one of the best jobs I had as a college student. The only thing that I can think of is that there is no clear boss some time.

pros: Working here is great, especially if you're a student who has bills to pay. Loved the work culture and my coworkers were especially kind.
cons: Can be hard to maintain the work/school balance, and the pay could be more for the amount of work I had to do. Not many benefits.

pros:
Continue at university while working there
Flexibility for working and taking classes
Centrally located with access to public transportation
cons:
Lacking cohesiveness as a university department
Lack of understanding among some staff about policies and procedures
Lack of healthy communication within organization

job_title: Integrated Digital Support Center Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: it was relatively easy and I gained a lot of information there. I loved the free lynda training available to all the workers.
cons: You can't work full time there, you are limited to 27 hours a week. It is also hard to deal with faculty members that work there.

pros: As a student worker I really enjoyed the camaraderie with the other student workers in PSU Housing Department. We became a family over the course of the two years I worked with them.

pros: As a PSU student, I was awarded a contract through PSU to work at a large local hospital. The PSU HR employees who facilitated this opportunity were professional and helpful at every turn.

pros: It was easy to get employed as a student at Portland state; the school does a much better job with it than other schools that I have been to.

job_title: Computer Lab Attendant in Portland, OR
pros: Working at Portland State helped give me a sense of community. I learned some technical skills can help me in future jobs.

pros: Their business school and expertise there is great. Also some of the professors are that good that they would deserve a better school and resources.
